content:
• In che percorso è installato Thunderbird?
  • E in che percorso si trova il profilo utente di Thunderbird? -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird
  • Ci sono altri account Gmail già configurati?
  • Hai un antivirus? ne hai controllato il log per assicurarti che non cancelli file di Thunderbird?
  • Usi software per la pulizia/ottimizzazione del sistema?

content: U kunt Thunderbird opnieuw downloaden vanaf https://www.thunderbird.net/nl/ en installeren. Afhankelijk van de de-installatie is het mogelijk dat alle gegevens nog wel in het profiel staan en zal Thunderbird deze vinden. Geen profiel gevonden, dan is het hopen op een back-up.

content:
According to Spectrum, a tampabay.rr.com account should use these settings:

outgoing server mail.brighthouse.com on port 587, STARTTLS security, authentication = normal password, User Name = email address.

It might also work with the same settings except the server is mail.twc.com.

content: That error appears if you have multiple accounts that aren't matching the smtp User Name with the incoming User Name. But since you have just one account, check (again) that the User Name (email address) in Account Settings, Server Settings, is the same as the User Name for the Outgoing (and check that there is only a single smtp server).

creator: kdunn004

content:
You can't set 'no authentication' if the provider doesn't allow it. If you weren't required to enter a password, anyone could send mail from your account. When you see the password prompt, check the box to have it stored in Saved Passwords, so you don't have to enter it each time (see picture).

The instructions from Spectrum/TWC have never been totally clear, as you will see by searching this forum for related issues.
creator: sfhowes

content: If I understand correctly, you are attempting to access Gmail online with the password used by Thunderbird. It does not work. Google assigns a unique code to your PC, to be used only by that PC, no other. To access Gmail website, you need the 'real' password.
creator: davidsk

content: If Thunderbird uses a unique code to access Gmail, then why does it store the email passwords within the program itself?
creator: mastump317

content: Where you prefer to have it stored?

content: I found the solution myself. It is the file prefs.js containing the info. I changed the value for layout.css.devPixelsPerPx back -1.0 and Thunderbird worked again as before. Great sigh of relief.....

content: Dan is het nodig om de instellingen van de mailservers (SMTP) te controleren, zoals uitgelegd op deze pagina: https://support.mozilla.org/nl/kb/kan-geen-berichten-verzenden#w_verifieer-uw-smtp-instellingen-voor-uitgaande-e-mail.
creator: Mozilla-assistent

content: - go to windows file explorer, assuming you use windows - locate the profile folder - the message folder would be in the Imapmail folder for IMAP account, or the Mail folder for POP - ignore the .msf files - open the desired folder in notepad and search for the message with the pin. - the profile is at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles\<your profile name> - the profiles.ini text file in the thunderbird folder will identify the profile folder
creator: davidsk

content: Maybe an indexing problem? Disable that filter > move that message back to the Inbox > try R. click Inbox > Properties > Repair folder.

content: Did you try creating a new addressbook, and then importing to just it? Thunderbird gives that option, but you must FIRST create the new, empty list.
creator: davidsk

content:
The problem is that an "address book" and an "address list" are two different entities.

Yes you CAN create a list within an address book, and use the import function, but in stage 2 you are asked where you want to import to - and you're only given names of address books, not lists.

Which would be fine, but you can't use the name of an address book in the To: field when writing a message.
creator: dheadey

content: A possibility is to exit thunderbird and copy all abook* files from one profile to the other.
creator: davidsk

content: Where would I find the files in the profile please?
creator: dheadey

content: You can locate the profile this way: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down left side to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' - exit thunderbird - you are now in the profile. If you list the entries alphabetically, there will be a number of entries beginning with abook. Those are the addressbooks. Copy to the other PC the same way.

content: I do not have the answer, but if deleting that file works, it is in your profile. That link you showed was for another person's profile. If you locate your profile at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles\<your-profile-name> You will see the global file. Delete it and restart thunderbird. Browsing the text file, profiles.ini in the thunderbird folder will tell you the name of the specific profile. Do post back if that works.
creator: davidsk

content: After finding the hidden appdata folder, I got to C:\Users\smb2\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles. (smb2 is my profile) The only folders there are hgp4cw05.personal & yacmgsik.default. Although each has several sqlite files, none are named global-messages-db.sqlite. Any suggestions? Thanks.
creator: smb21

content:
Okay, this calls for desperate measures. Now that you know where the profiles are, my approach would be to: - exit thunderbird - copy the above c:\users\smb2\appdata\roaming\thunderbird elsewhere. That is everything you would need in case of a problem to reconfigure profile - uninstall thunderbird - install thunderbird again - start thunderbird - if it picks the profile as desired, you're done - if it presents screen to create email account, it somehow didn't see the profile. so, 

  - exit thunderbird    - copy the backed up thunderbird folder back to where you copied if from. windows will prompt that it will replace files. that's ok

- now restart thunderbird and all should be there.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thanks again for your time with this; problems continue. When I tried to uninstall, there were 2 versions of TB, with the following results (neither could be uninstalled):

Mozilla Thunderbird (x64 en-US) 462 MB 115.12.1 6/22/2024 This led back to the reboot loop ("Your computer must be restarted to complete a previous upgrade of Thunderbird. Do you want to reboot now?").

Mozilla Thunderbird (x86 en-US) 439 MB 115.3.1 10/1/2023 This generated: "Windows cannot find 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Mozilla Thunderbird\uninstall\helper.exe'. Make sure you typed the name correctly, and then try again."

What's next?
creator: smb21

content: I would remove the entry at c:\program files\Mozila Thunderbird, and rename c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\tunderbird to ensure your profile contents are not lost, but can be copied back later. Then, see if you can do an install of 64-bit thunderbird. If you are comfortable with the registry, I would suggest to do a registry search and delete all entries with thunderbird.exe in them.
creator: davidsk

content: I did everything you suggested, except delete registry files, and Thunderbird is now running well. I had to copy the old roaming folder to see sub-folders and previously received mail. Thanks so much!

creator: dfujikaw

content: If you need a new password, you must go to email provider's site. If it's a valid email password, then the account settings may be wrong. I still do not understand your specific situation. That is, since you have a password, why do you need to reset it? If you want to remove existing password, click settings>privacy&security and then click 'saved passwords' and then 'show passwords' - and then highlight and right-click to edit, where you can delete it, or highllight rows for the account and delete both. Then thunderbird will have no password and you can reset it.
creator: davidsk

content: Since the old messages are to be an archive, I propose doing it the simplest way: put the old messages on each PC. Yes, there are fancy ways to make accessible from one platform, but it's messy and problem-prone. Here would be my dirt-simple approach: - if the importexporttools addon is not installed, install on both PCs. - on the desktop PC, highlight each folder to be saved as archive (such as the POP inbox) - then right-click and use the importexport menu to export as mbox - repeat for all folders to be shared from the POP account - on both PCs, in Local Folders, create a new folder for each of the folders you exported. - now, for each saved folder, highlight one of the new local folders, right-click and select the importexport menu to import mbox and select one of the desired saved folders - repeat for all folders - you're done.
creator: davidsk
